module.name: ExtCtrls
module.short: Some extra controls commonly used in Lazarus forms

element.name: TPageFlag
element.short: TPageFlag - enumerated type containing possible values for page flags for notebook pages

descr.p: TPageFlag - enumerated type containing possible values for page flags for notebook pages
descr.pre: pfAdded, // handle of page added to notebook handle pfAdding, // currently handle of page adding to notebook handle pfRemoving, // currently removing page handle from notebook handle pfInserting // currently inserting page into notebook

element.name: TPageFlag.pfAdded
element.short: Internal flag set after page handle was connected to the notebook handle

element.name: TPageFlags
element.short: TPageFlags - set of TPageFlag

element.name: TPage
element.short: TPage: One of the pages in a tabbed Notebook

descr.p: TPage: One of the pages in a tabbed Notebook
Inherits most of its properties from TCustomPage

element.name: TNotebook
element.short: TNotebook is a container for a series of pages placed together

descr.p: TNotebook is a control which can hold a series of pages placed together. Only one page is shown at a time and this control is completely custom drawn, which means that it is available and looks the same in any widgetset which supports TCustomControl. The pages are containers which can hold controls. This control never has tabs. If you are looking for a control with tabs and pages, please see TPageControl instead.

To use a Notebook, select its icon from the 'Additional' tab of the Component Palette and place it on the Form. Adjust its size, position, alignment and anchoring as required, by moving the object on the Form or by using the Object Inspector.

Pages are added to the NoteBook by selecting the control and right-clicking with the mouse to get a pop-up menu whose first item is 'Add Page'. Pages already in the NoteBook can be edited by selecting the appropriate ActivePage in the Object Inspector and modifying its properties or adding additional components to that Page.

element.name: TNotebook.Options
element.short: Set of Options for this Notebook. Include nboShowCloseButtons, nboMultiLine

descr.p: Set of Options for this Notebook. Include nboShowCloseButtons, nboMultiLine
To use the Options, select the tag in the Object Inspector, then select for inclusion any of the listed options, setting them True or False as appropriate.

For example, setting nboShowCloseButtons to True will cause a CloseButton (a small CheckBox with an 'x' in it) to appear on each Tab of the NoteBook, allowing the tabbed Page to be closed when the user clicks on the CloseButton.

element.name: TTimer
element.short: TTimer: An elapsed timer useful in many applications

descr.p: TTimer: An elapsed timer useful in many applications
Inherits most of its properties from TCustomTimer

descr.p: TIdleTimerAutoEvent - enumerated class containing events relevant to a timer

element.name: TIdleTimerAutoEvents
element.short: TIdleTimerAutoEvents - set of TIdleTimerAutoEvent

element.name: TIdleTimer
element.short: TIdleTimer : A timer to measure idle time between processes

descr.p: TIdleTimer: A timer to measure idle time between processes

element.name: TIdleTimer.SetAutoEnabled

element.name: TIdleTimer.DoOnIdle

element.name: TIdleTimer.Destroy

element.name: TShapeType
element.short: TShapeType - enumerated type containing several standard geometric shapes

descr.p: TShapeType - enumerated type containing several standard geometric shapes:
descr.pre: stRectangle stSquare stRoundRect stRoundSquare stEllipse stCircle stSquaredDiamond stDiamond

element.name: TShape
element.short: TShape - An arbitrary graphic geometrical shape placed on the Form. It may be one of a series of standard shapes defined by TShapeType

descr.p: TShape: An arbitrary graphic geometrical shape placed on the Form. It may be one of a series of standard shapes defined by TShapeType (stRectangle, stSquare, stRoundRect, stRoundSquare, stEllipse, stCircle, stSquaredDiamond, stDiamond).
It can be displayed using the Paint method and the Brush and Pen tools.

element.short: Create - constructor for TShape: calls inherited Create, sets default styles and bounds, creates pen and brush

element.name: TShape.Destroy

stRectangle,
stSquare,
stRoundRect,
stRoundSquare,
stEllipse,
stCircle,
stSquaredDiamond,
stDiamond

element.name: TResizeStyle
element.short: TResizeStyle - enumerated type for style of resizing using splitters
element.descr: rsLine - draw a line, don't update splitter position during moving rsNone - draw nothing and don't update splitter position during moving rsPattern - draw a dot pattern, don't update splitter position during moving rsUpdate - draw nothing, update splitter position during moving

element.name: TCanResizeEvent
element.short: TCanResizeEvent - generic event handling method for resizing using splitter

element.name: TCustomSplitter
element.short:
TCustomSplitter : the base type for
TSplitter

descr.p:
TCustomSplitter: the base type for
TSplitter
A Splitter is a vertical or horizontal bar that can be placed on a panel or form, to separate sub-panels functionally and allow re-sizing of the constituent sub-panels
This class defines many of the basic properties for the children classes, such as positioning, sizing and alignment
descr.pre: { TCustomSplitter is a control for interactively resizing another control. It is a vertical or horizontal bar anchored to a side of a control. You can either set the Align property to alLeft (alRight,alTop,alBottom), then it will become a vertical bar, aligned to the left and when the user moves it with the mouse, the control to the left with the same Align=alLeft will be resized. The second more flexible possibility is to set the properties Align=alNone, AnchorSides and ResizeAnchor. }

element.name: TCustomSplitter.FindAlignOtherControl
element.short: FindAlignOtherControl - returns another alignment control (the splitter may have to align two controls)

element.name: TCustomSplitter.StartSplitterMove
element.short: StartSplitterMove - method for starting movement of the splitter, given the mouse position MouseXY

element.name: TCustomSplitter.FindAlignControl
element.short: FindAlignControl - returns the main alignment control

element.name: TCustomSplitter.CheckAlignment
element.short: CheckAlignment - ensure control is correctly aligned

element.name: TCustomSplitter.CheckNewSize
element.short: CheckNewSize - ensure new size is appropriate: returns True if sucessful

element.name: TCustomSplitter.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomSplitter: calls inherited Create then sets initial alignment, size and style

element.name: TCustomSplitter.ResizeStyle
element.short: Style for resizing - as a line, a pattern, full update, or none

element.name: TCustomSplitter.AutoSnap
element.short: AutoSnap - automatically snaps to a grid point or grid line in the Form designer
element.descr: Boolean property, true if snapping to grid positions

element.name: TCustomSplitter.Beveled
element.short: Whether the edges of the splitter bar are bevelled

element.name: TCustomSplitter.MinSize
element.short: Minimum size for splitter - default 30 pixels

element.name: TCustomSplitter.OnCanResize
element.short: Event handler for receiving permission to resize

element.name: TCustomSplitter.OnMoved
element.short: Event handler for occasion when splitter has moved

element.name: TCustomSplitter.AnchorSplitter
element.short: AnchorSplitter - anchor the splitter to Acontrol using the specified Kind of anchor

element.name: TCustomSplitter.ResizeControl
element.short: ResizeControl - the control that is to be re-sized with the splitter

element.name: TCustomSplitter.GetOtherResizeControl
element.short: GetOtherResizeControl - find out which other control is to be re-sized

element.name: TCustomSplitter.MoveSplitter
element.short: MoveSplitter - by an amount specified by Offset

element.name: TCustomSplitter.SetSplitterPosition
element.short: SetSplitterPosition - to specified NewPosition

element.name: TCustomSplitter.GetSplitterPosition
element.short: GetSplitterPosition - returns the current position of the splitter

element.name: TCustomSplitter.ResizeAnchor
element.short: ResizeAnchor - the kind of anchor to be used for resizing

element.name: TSplitter
element.short: TSplitter : A vertical or horizontal bar placed on a panel or form, to separate sub-panels functionally

descr.p: TSplitter: A vertical or horizontal bar that can be placed on a panel or form, to separate sub-panels functionally and allow re-sizing of the constituent sub-panels

The splitter extends for the full height (if vertical) or full width (if horizontal) of the parent control (form or panel) and is anchored to the edges; its position along the length or height of the parent is determined by the programmer or user by moving the whole control with the mouse, and its size can be adjusted using the sizing bars and with the ResizeAnchor property

element.name: TPaintBox
element.short: TPaintBox: a painted rectangular box with defined size and color

descr.p: TPaintBox: a painted rectangular box with defined size and colour

element.name: TPaintBox.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TPaintBox: calls inherited Create then sets initial bounds and style

Picture
- the actual image for display

element.name: TCustomImage.Transparent

element.name: TCustomImage.Proportional

element.name: TImage
element.short: TImage - a graphic image placed on the form; usually loaded from a picture file.

TImage
: a graphic image placed on the form; usually loaded from a picture file.
The actual image is found in Picture or Canvas
Inherits most of its properties from its ancestors, TCustomImage, TGraphicControl and TControl

element.name: TBevelStyle
element.short: TBevelStyle - enumerated type for bevel style: lowered or raised

element.name: TBevelShape
element.short: TBevelShape - enumerated type for shape of bevel

descr.p: TBevelShape - enumerated type for shape of bevel
descr.pre: bsBox bsFrame bsTopLine bsBottomLine bsLeftLine bsRightLine

element.name: TBevel
element.short: A bevel placed around the edge of buttons and other components

descr.p: Its appearance is governed by and

element.name: TBevel.Paint
element.descr: Virtual Paint method called in response to paint requests received by the parent control.

element.name: TBevel.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TBevel: calls inherited Create then sets initial style, shape and bounds

descr.p: Either reads a flag containing alignment instructions (FAlign) or writes alignment instructions (SetAlign)
May have no alignment, may have custom or client alignment, or can be aligned to top, bottom, left or right
Determines how the control is to be anchored to its parent control
Either reads a flag containing the set of anchors to be used, or writes a set of anchors. If they have been written, this is indicated in IsAnchorsStored
Determines the border spacing for this control
Reads flag to find stored spacing values required for the border of the control, or writes the flag to set the spacing.
The properties are defined in the parent class TControlBorderSpacing
Determine Constraints (max and min height and width) for this control; reads the size constraints or stores new ones.

element.name: TBevel.Name
element.descr: Name is the name of the component. This name should be a valid identifier, i.e. must start with a letter, and can contain only letters, digits and the underscore character. When attempting to set the name of a component, the name will be checked for validity. Furthermore, when a component is owned by another component, the name must be either empty or must be unique among the child component names.
element.errors: Attempting to set the name to an invalid value will result in an exception being raised.

element.name: TBevel.Shape
element.short: Shape - whether a box, a frame or a line along one of the edges

element.name: TBevel.Style
element.short: Style - whether raised or lowered

descr.pre: The Visible property represents the ability to see a visual control. If Visible is True the control is shown, otherwise it is hidden. Calling Show sets, among others, Visible to True. Setting Visible to False is equivalent to calling Hide method.
descr.remark: The Visible property does not depend on control's parent visibility. Use IsVisible method to consider this and get real visibility.

element.name: TColumnLayout
element.short: TColumnLayout - enumerated type for layout where data are arranged in columns

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup
element.short: TCustomRadioGroup: the base type for TRadioGroup

descr.p: A group of related but mutually exclusive radio buttons, selectable by the user.

This class defines Items, where the captions of the individual radio boxes are stored, Rows and Columns for arranging the radio boxes, and ColumnLayout to determine whether the data are arranged down the columns first, or across the rows first.

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.UpdateRadioButtonStates
element.short: UpdateRadioButtonStates including implementing any pending changes

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.SetColumns
element.short: SetColumns - specifies the number of columns for displaying the items

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.SetItemIndex
element.short: SetItemIndex - specifies an index for an item

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.GetItemIndex
element.short: GetItemIndex - returns an index for an item

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.ItemIndex
element.short: The Index value in the list of Items (a stringlist with the names of the selections for radio buttons)

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Items
element.short: Items - a string list containing the captions for the radio boxes

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Columns
element.short:
Columns - the number of columns in which the
Items (radio buttons) are to be arranges

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.ColumnLayout
element.short:
ColumnLayout -
HorizontalThenVertical or vice versa

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomRadioGroup: calls inherited Create, then sets list of buttons, and initialises layout and sizing properties

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Destroy
element.short: Destroy - destructor for TCustomRadioGroup: frees items and buttons, then calls inherited Destroy

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.CanModify
element.short: CanModify - if True, modification of the RadioGroup is permitted

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Rows
element.short: Rows - the number of rows in which Items (radio boxes) are held

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.Rows.Result
element.short: Number of rows

element.name: TRadioGroup
element.short: TRadioGroup : A group of related but mutually exclusive radio buttons, requiring the user to select one af a set of alternatives

descr.p: TRadioGroup: A group of related but mutually exclusive radio buttons, requiring the user to select one af a set of alternatives. As one button becomes selected, the remaining buttons in the group become automatically deselected.

To Use this control, place it in the required position on the form, then in the Object Inspector select Items and click on the ellipsis (...) to open the string editor. Type in the captions to accompany each check box, then close the string editor and you will see a series of Radio Boxes with their captions displayed beside them. (Note - unlike TCheckGroup, there is no special RadioGroup editor)
Inherits properties from TCustomRadioGroup and TCustomGroupBox

TRadioGroup behaves differently from a group of
TRadioButton controls placed arbitrarily around a form.

In the case of TRadioButton, the mutual exclusivity is a feature that applies to any RadioButton anywhere in the Form, and the RadioButtons can be rearranged in any order or placed anywhere within the containing Form, while in TRadioGroup the exclusivity applies only to buttons within the Group, which are ordered strictly according to their ItemIndex within the Items stringlist.

TRadioButton is an entity in itself, with a number of additional properties, whereas the buttons within
TRadioGroup are not separate entities, but rather are simply entries in a list of strings, each of which is associated with the on-screen image of a
RadioButton.
The example shows the difference between the use of TRadioButton and TRadioGroup

element.name: TRadioGroup.Caption
element.short: Caption - the text string appearing above the whole RadioGroup box

element.name: TRadioGroup.Items
element.short: Items - a string list containing the captions of the radio boxes

descr.p: Items - a string list containing the captions of the radio boxes

Use the String List editor, opened by selecting Items and the ellipsis (...) in the Object Inspector, to insert the captions for the radio boxes, and determine their order and layout using the Rows, Columns and ColumnLayout properties

element.name: TCheckGroupClicked
element.short: TCheckGroupClicked - generic event handler method for a click in a check group

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup
element.short:
TCustomCheckGroup: The base type for
TCheckGroup

descr.p:
TCustomCheckGroup: The base type for
TCheckGroup

This class defines Items, where the captions for individual check boxes are stored, Rows and Columns for arranging the check boxes, and ColumnLayout to determine whether the data are arranged down the columns first, or across the rows first.

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.SetItems
element.short: SetItems - specify the strings that form the Items of the group

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.SetColumns
element.short: SetColumns - specifies the nuber of coulmns in which the Items are arranged

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.DefineProperties
element.short: DefineProperties - overrides the method inherited from TComponent, defines the top, left properties

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.ReadData
element.short: Reads data from a stream

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.WriteData
element.short: Writes Data to a stream

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomCheckGroup: calls inherited Create, then sets styles, creates lists, initialises sizing and layout properties

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Destroy
element.short: Destroy - destructor for TCustomCheckGroup: frees items and buttons, then calls inherited Destroy

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Rows
element.short: Rows - the number of rows in which the Items (check boxes) are arranged

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Rows.Result
element.short: The number of rows holding items

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Items
element.short: Items - a string list for the captions of the check boxes

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Checked
element.short: Whether an individual entry in the list is Checked

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.CheckEnabled
element.short: CheckEnabled - whether a given (indexed) entry in the list is allowed to be checked

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.Columns
element.short:
Columns - the number of columns in which the
Items (check boxes) are to be arranges

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.ColumnLayout
element.short:
ColumnLayout -
HorizontalThenVertical or vice versa

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.OnItemClick
element.short: OnItemClick - event handler for mouse click on one of the Items in the Check Group

element.name: TCustomCheckGroup.AutoFill
element.short: AutoFill - whether Check Boxes should be automatically filled in (checked)

element.name: TCheckGroup
element.short: TCheckGroup : A group of Check Boxes physically and logically grouped together on a form

descr.p: TCheckGroup: A group of Check Boxes physically and logically grouped together on a form

To Use this control, place it in the required position on the form, then either right-click on the control to see the pop-up CheckGroup editor, or in the Object Inspector select Items and click on the ellipsis (...) to open the string editor. In either case, type in the captions to accompany each check box, then close the string or CheckGroup editor and you will see a series of boxes with their captions displayed beside them.
Inherits properties from TCustomCheckGroup and TCustomGroupBox

element.name: TCheckGroup.Caption
element.short: Caption: the string which appears at the top of the Check Group Box

descr.p: Caption: the string which appears as a caption at the top of the Check Group Box to describe the function of the Check Group as a whole

element.name: TCheckGroup.Items
element.short: Items - a string list containing the captions of the check boxes

descr.p: Items - a string list containing the captions of the check boxes
Use the String List editor or the CheckGroup editor (opened by right-clicking on the control in the Form) to insert the captions for the check boxes, and determine their order and layout

element.name: TBoundLabel
element.short:
TBoundLabel: A label bound to another object, for example in
TLabeledEdit

TBoundLabel: A label bound to another object, for example in
TLabeledEdit

TCustomLabeledEdit
: The base type for
LabeledEdit.
Note particularly the EditLabel property (see TBoundLabel), which contains the label attached to the Edit control.

LabelPosition

LabelSpacing
- the distance between the Label and the Edit box

element.name: TLabeledEdit
element.short: Labelled Edit: An Edit Box with a permanently attached Label

descr.p:
TLabeledEdit
: An Edit Box with a permanently attached Label
Saves time and effort over placing separate Label and Edit Box on Form. The properties are described in the parent component, TCustomLabeledEdit from which most of the properties are inherited

element.name: TLabeledEdit.Text

Text

element.name: TCustomPanel
element.short:
TCustomPanel: The base type for
TPanel

descr.p:
TCustomPanel: The base type for
TPanel
A Panel is a defined rectangular area of the form into which other components can be placed to group them functionally and geographically.
TCustomPanel defines the positioning and bevelling properties of any descendent classes, and provides methods for painting and writing text to the panel.

element.name: TCustomPanel.UpdateBordersAndBevels
element.short: UpdateBordersAndBevels - make sure any changes to borders and bevels are accurately shown

element.name: TCustomPanel.UpdateParentColorChange
element.short: UpdateParentColorChange - update any pending changes in parent colour

element.name: TCustomPanel.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomPanel: calls inherited Create then sets initial style, bevel, colour, alignment and bounds

element.name: TCustomPanel.Alignment
element.short: Alignment - whether text is left or right justified, or centered

element.name: TCustomPanel.BevelInner
element.short: BevelInner - determines the nature of the Inner Bevel of the panel (whether raised, lowered etc)

element.name: TCustomPanel.BevelOuter
element.short: BevelOuter - determines the nature of the Outer Bevel of the panel (whether raised, lowered etc)

element.name: TCustomPanel.BevelWidth
element.short: BevelWidth - the Width of the panel's bevel in pixels

element.name: TCustomPanel.FullRepaint
element.short: FullRepaint - if True, the panel needs to be fully repainted after each change

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon
element.short:
TCustomTrayIcon - the base class for
TTrayIcon, a multiplatform System Tray component.

element.name: TTrayIcon
element.short: TTrayIcon is a multiplatform System Tray component. It adds an icon to the tray and signifies an application that is inactive but ready to be activated. Under Windows the System tray is usually located on the bottom-right corner of the screen, but it may be elsewhere. On other operating systems this position varies.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Create
element.descr: Create creates a new instance of a TCustomTrayIcon class. If AOwner is not Nil, the new component attempts to insert itself in the list of owned components of the owner.
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomTrayIcon: performs inherited Create then creates icon, timer and initialises balloon timeout

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Destroy
element.descr: Destroy sends a opRemove notification to all components in the free-notification list. After that, all owned components are destroyed by calling DestroyComponents (and hence removed from the list of owned components). When this is done, the component removes itself from its owner's child component list. After that, the parent's destroy method is called.
element.short: Destroy - destructor for TCustomTrayIcon: frees icon and timer then calls inherited Destroy

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Hide
element.short: Hide - Removes the icon from the System Tray

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Show
element.short: Show - Shows the icon on the System Tray

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.ShowBalloonHint
element.short: ShowBalloonHint displays a smal balloon-like window near the tray icon. It can be used to send notifications about the status of an action, or notify of a received message or any other event which doesn't require an imediate response. The Ballon window disappears after BallonHintTimeout milliseconds or when the user clicks it or it's close button.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.GetPosition
element.short: Find the position of the Tray Icon and thus a position suitable to display the hinting BalloonHint. Under Windows an approximate location is detected.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.BalloonFlags
element.short: the set of kinds of balloon flag that can be displayed (may be None, Info, Warning or Error)

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.BalloonHint
element.short: The text to be shown in the hinting balloon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.BalloonTimeout
element.short: The period after which the hinting balloon disappears

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.BalloonTitle
element.short: The title to be shown on the hinting balloon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Canvas
element.short: The canvas of the Tray Icon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.PopUpMenu
element.short: PopUpMenu - a popup menu which is displayed when right mouse button is clicked over icon - separate from hint balloon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Icon
element.short: The Icon or picture that is to be displayed

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Hint
element.short: A simple hint that is shown when the mouse hovers over the icon.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.ShowIcon
element.short: Determines if Icon should be painted to the System Tray. This can be set to false if one wishes to instead paint to the Canvas of the Tray Icon.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Visible
element.short: It is set to true when the icon is shown and remains true until Hide is called. Setting Visible has the same effect as calling Hide or Show.

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnClick
element.short: Event Handler for Mouse Click on Tray Icon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnDblClick
element.short: Event handler for mouse double-click

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnMouseDown
element.short: Event handler if mouse button is pressed down

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnMouseUp
element.short: Event handler if mouse button is up

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnMouseMove
element.short: Event handler for mouse movement

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.OnPaint
element.short: Use this to implement custom drawing to the icon. Draw using the canvas property of the icon. Note: Does not work on win32.

descr.p:
Assign copies the contents of
Source to
Self, if the classes of the destination and source classes are compatible.

The TPersistent implementation of Assign does nothing but calling the AssignTo method of source. This means that if the destination class does not know how to assign the contents of the source class, the source class instance is asked to assign itself to the destination class. This means that it is necessary to implement only one of the two methods so that two classes can be assiged to one another.

remark.p: In general, a statement of the form
(where Destination and Source are classes) does not achieve the same as a statement of the form
After the former statement, both Source and Destination will point to the same object. The latter statemtent will copy the contents of the Source class to the Destination class.

topic.name: Multi-PageControls
topic.short: Multi-PageControls - controls that offer a selection of alternative pages for display

descr.p: Multi-PageControls - controls that offer a selection of alternative pages for display

A number of controls, found in Units ExtCtrls and ComCtrls, offer the ability to create multi-page forms with a series of Tabs along one edge that allow the user to select one of the Pages for display and interaction.

These include: TPageControl, TNoteBook, TTabControl and THeaderControl (the Header Control components have a very different structure and function). Icons for all of these exist on the Additional or Common Controls tabs of the Component Palette in the Lazarus IDE.
While the various components may look superficially similar, they differ in properties, inheritance, method of adding additional pages, behaviour at run-time, methods for referencing pages and so on.

We have to be very clear when using the various properties, to distinguish between the word 'Tab' as referring to a Tab indicating an identifier for a page, and 'Tab' as referring to the TAB key on the standard keyboard. In common with most Lazarus components, it is possible to enable each control to be included in the TabOrder of TabStops for a Form, so that the component can be reached by repeated pressing of the TAB key, and we must not confuse this use of 'Tab' with the use to denote a Page.
The properties CanTab, TabStop and TabOrder refer to the use of the TAB key to navigate to the relevant control.
Properties such as Tabs, TabIndex, IndexOfTabAt(), TabIndexAtClientPos(), TabPosition, TabHeight, TabWidth, TabVisible, OnCloseTabClicked refer to the use for Page selection.

TTabControl and
TPageControl are both descended from
TCustomNoteBook (which is in turn descended from
TWinControl) and have many inherited properties in common.
TPageControl has, in general, more advanced features and is probably intended to replace
TNoteBook.
The following table summarises the main differences between the two components.

tr.td:
TTabSheet, a more advanced version of
TPage
Drag properties, but minimal Dock or Drop
Full Drag, Drop, Dock properties and methods
Published property Options, include nboShowCloseButtons, nboMultiLine
No published Options property, but inherits Options (public property) from TCustomNoteBook, so they could be set explicitly in code

descr.p: The individual Pages in both of the above controls (descended from TCustomNoteBook) are separate and can have their own specific collections of widgets which appear only when the relevant Page is selected by its Tab.

In contrast, the TTabControl component (descended from TCustomTabControl) has only one display area (Protected property DisplayRect), but the image displayed in it is determined by which tab has been selected. Each Tab has an index value which is used to select the appropriate image from an indexed ImageList and display it in the Display Rectangle.

The properties of the Tabs in TTabControl are very configurable compared with those in the controls derived from TCustomNoteBook, allowing for instance the creation of multi-line captions, the placement of images on Tabs, the possibility of the Owner routine determining the drawing of the tab, the configuration of Tab size, the selection of multiple tabs. The trade-off is that the display area is restricted in what it can display, and is essentially confined to display of images.

To use any of the above controls, select them from the relevant tab on the IDE Component Palette and drop them on the form in the required position. Fill in as many relevant properties as you can in the Object Inspector.

To add Tabs or Pages to the controls, select the control with a left mouse click or by selecting from the Component menu in the Object Inspector, then right-click on the component to get a pop-up menu, whose first item will be 'Add Page' or 'Add Tab'.
The Tabs in TTabControl can be edited by selecting 'Tabs' in the Object Inspector, clicking on the ellipsis (...) and using the string editor that pops up.
The pages inTNoteBook or TPageControl can be edited by selecting the ActivePage in the Object Inspector and then editing the properties of the individual page.

THeaderControl offers a widget that could be placed along the edge of a Panel or Form, allowing a highly customised mechanism for selection. However, there are no intrinsically associated display areas, and it is the developer's responsibility to supply an index associated with the selection from the
THeaderControl and determining what action is to occur or what is to be displayed in any attached Panel or Form.

When the control is first selected from the Component Palette and placed on a Form, it consists of an unadorned rectangle. However, selecting the control and right-clicking (or selecting the 'Sections' property in the Object Inspector) gives access to a Sections editor (a StringList editor) and Sections can be added to the control. The sections are separated by vertical lines, and each section can have a string inserted as a label, associated with an Index value. The Sections can be rearranged, re-ordered, or be individually painted.

In a typical application a THeaderControl and a TPanel or TForm would be docked together, and code would be written to find which Section of the Header had been selected, then use its index to control the display in the other docked control.

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.SetItems
element.short: SetItems - specifies the strings that form the Items of the group

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.CheckItemIndexChanged
element.short: CheckItemIndexChanged - find out if the index for an item has changes

element.name: TCustomRadioGroup.AutoFill
element.short: AutoFill - whether responses to Items should automatically be filled in

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.Handle
element.short: Operating system Handle for the Tray Icon

element.name: TCustomTrayIcon.InternalUpdate
element.short: InternalUpdate - updates any pending changes
element.descr: The behavior of this method depends on the widgetset and it was added to provide an way to update items which either cannot be updated automatically upon change or would be too inneficient to be updated on each change. One example of this is the tray icon menu under LCL-Carbon. It is not automatically updated when changes are done to it's associated LCL TPopUpMenu, but changes are updated when InternalUpdate is called. This happens because the tray icon menus are Cocoa menus which don't match the Carbon menus from LCL-Carbon. Similar things happen in various other widgetsets, so InternalUpdate can be expected to update the menu and/or icon of the tray icon, if this is necessary. If such an update is not required, for example because it is automatically updated on each change, then InternalUpdate will simply do nothing, so it is always a safe function to call, regardless of the widgetset.

element.name: TCustomImage.OnPictureChanged
element.short: OnPictureChanged - event handler for a change in the picture

element.name: TBalloonFlags
element.short: TBalloonFlags enumerated type for flags on Tray Icon balloons

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer
element.short: TCustomIdleTimer - base class for TIdleTimer

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.SetAutoEnabled
element.short: SetAutoEnabled puts the supplied boolean value into the AutoEnabled property and updates handlers

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.DoOnIdle
element.short: DoOnIdle - action to be taken if the timer is idle

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.DoOnIdleEnd
element.short: DoOnIdleEnd -action to be taken at the end of an idle period

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.DoOnUserInput
element.short: DoOnUserInput - action to be taken when user input is detected

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.Loaded
element.short: Loaded - calls inherited method and updates Handlers

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.Create
element.short: Create - constructor for TCustomIdleTimer: calls inherited Create and initialises some local event variables

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.Destroy
element.short: Destroy - destructor for TCustomIdleTimer: calls inherited Destroy after setting the AutoEnabled property False

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.AutoEnabled
element.short: AutoEnabled - if True, Timer is automatically enabled

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.AutoStartEvent
element.short: AutoStartEvent - the event that triggers autostart (either idle time-out or user input)

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.AutoEndEvent
element.short: AutoEndEvent - the event that causes the automatic end of the timer

element.name: TCustomIdleTimer.FireOnIdle
element.short: FireOnIdle - boolean property determining whether the timer should fire when idle
